34.30: Because the hypocrite doth reign, and because the people are snared.
34.31: Surely it appertaineth unto God to say, I have pardoned, I will not destroy.
34.32: But if I see not, teach thou me: if I have done wickedly, I will do no more.
34.33: Will he perform the thing through thee? for thou hast reproved it, because that thou hast chosen, and not I: now speak what thou knowest.
34.34: Let men of understanding tell me, and let a wise man hearken unto me.
34.35: Job hath not spoken of knowledge, neither were his words according to wisdom.
34.36: I desire that Job may be tried, unto the end, touching the answers for wicked men.
34.37: For he addeth rebellion unto his sin, he clappeth his hands among us, and multiplieth his words against God.

35.2: Thinkest thou this right, that thou hast said, I am more righteous than God?
35.3: For thou hast said, What profiteth it thee, and what availeth it me, to purge me from my sin?
35.4: Therefore will I answer thee, and thy companions with thee.
35.5: Look unto the heaven, and see and behold the clouds which are higher than thou.
35.6: If thou sinnest, what doest thou against him, yea, when thy sins be many, what doest thou unto him?
35.7: If thou be righteous, what givest thou unto him? or what receiveth he at thine hand?
35.8: Thy wickedness may hurt a man as thou art: and thy righteousness may profit the son of man.
35.9: They cause many that are oppressed, to cry, which cry out for the violence of the mighty.
35.10: But none saith, Where is God that made me, which giveth songs in the night?
35.11: Which teacheth us more than the beasts of the earth, and giveth us more wisdom than the fowls of the heaven.
35.12: Then they cry because of the violence of the wicked, but he answereth not.
35.13: Surely God will not hear vanity, neither will the Almighty regard it.
35.14: Although thou sayest to God, Thou wilt not regard it, yet judgment is before him: trust thou in him.
35.15: But now because his anger hath not visited, nor called to count the evil with great extremity,
35.16: Therefore Job openeth his mouth in vain, and multiplieth words without knowledge.

36.2: Suffer me a little and I will instruct thee: for I have yet to speak on God’s behalf.
36.3: I will fetch my knowledge afar off, and will attribute righteousness unto my maker.
36.4: For truly my words shall not be false, and he that is perfect in knowledge, speaketh with thee.
36.5: Behold, the mighty God casteth away none that is mighty and valiant of courage.
36.6: He maintaineth not the wicked, but he giveth judgment to the afflicted.
36.7: He withdraweth not his eyes from the righteous, but they are with kings in the throne, where he placeth them forever: thus they are exalted.
36.8: And if they be bound in fetters and tied with the cords of affliction,
36.9: Then will he show them their work and their sins, because they have been proud.
36.10: He openeth also their ear to discipline, and commandeth them that they return from iniquity.
36.11: If they obey and serve him, they shall end their days in prosperity, and their years in pleasures:
36.12: But if they will not obey, they shall pass by the sword and perish without knowledge.
36.13: But the hypocrites of heart increase the wrath: for they call not when he bindeth them.
36.14: Their soul dieth in youth, and their life among the whoremongers.
36.15: He delivereth the poor in his afflictions, and openeth their ear in trouble.
36.16: Even so would he have taken thee out of the straight place into a broad place, and not shut up beneath: and that which resteth upon thy table had been full of fat.
36.17: But thou art full of the judgment of the wicked, though judgment and equity maintain all things.
36.18: For God’s wrath is, lest he should take thee away in thine abundance: for no multitude of gifts can deliver thee.
36.19: Will he regard thy riches? he regardeth not gold, nor all them that excel in strength.
36.20: Be not careful in the night, how he destroyeth the people out of their place.
36.21: Take thou heed: look not to iniquity: for thou hast chosen it rather than affliction.
36.22: Behold, God exalteth by his power: what teacher is like him?
36.23: Who hath appointed to him his way? or who can say, Thou hast done wickedly?
36.24: Remember that thou magnify his work, which men behold.
36.25: All men see it, and men behold it afar off.
36.26: Behold, God is excellent, and we know him not, neither can the number of his years be searched out.
36.27: When he restraineth the drops of water, the rain poureth down by the vapor thereof,
36.28: Which rain the clouds do drop and let fall abundantly upon man.
36.29: Who can know the divisions of the clouds, and the thunders of his Tabernacle?
36.30: Behold, he spreadeth his light upon it, and covereth the bottom of the sea.
36.31: For thereby he judgeth the people, and giveth meat abundantly.
36.32: He covereth the light with the clouds, and commanded them to go against it.
36.33: His companion showeth him therefore, and there is anger in rising up.

37.1: At this also mine heart is astonied, and is moved out of his place.
37.2: Hear the sound of his voice, and the noise that goeth out of his mouth.
37.3: He directeth it under the whole heaven, and his light unto the ends of the world.
37.4: After it a noise soundeth: he thundereth with the voice of his majesty, and he will not stay them when his voice is heard.
37.5: God thundereth marvelously with his voice: he worketh great things, which we know not.
37.6: For he saith to the snow, Be thou upon the earth likewise to the small rain and to the great rain of his power.
37.7: With the force thereof he shutteth up every man, that all men may know his work.
37.8: Then the beasts go into the den, and remain in their places.
37.9: The whirlwind cometh out of the South, and the cold from the North wind.
37.10: At the breath of God the frost is given, and the breadth of the waters is made narrow.
37.11: He maketh also the clouds to labor, to water the earth, and scattereth the cloud of his light.
37.12: And it is turned about by his government, that they may do whatsoever he commandeth them upon the whole world:
37.13: Whether it be for punishment, or for his land, or of mercy, he causeth it to come.
37.14: Hearken unto this, O Job: stand and consider the wondrous works of God.
37.15: Didst thou know when God disposed them? and caused the light of his cloud to shine?
37.16: Hast thou known the variety of the cloud, and the wondrous works of him that is perfect in knowledge?
37.17: Or how thy clothes are warm, when he maketh the earth quiet through the South wind?
37.18: Hast thou stretched out the heavens, which are strong, and as a molten glass?
37.19: Tell us what we shall say unto him: for we cannot dispose our matter because of darkness.
37.20: Shall it be told him when I speak? or shall man speak when he shall be destroyed?
37.21: And now men see not the light, which shineth in the clouds, but the wind passeth and cleanseth them.
37.22: The brightness cometh out of the North: the praise thereof is to God, which is terrible.
37.23: It is the Almighty: we cannot find him out: he is excellent in power and judgment, and abundant in justice: he afflicteth not.
37.24: Let men therefore fear him: for he will not regard any that are wise in their own conceit.

38.1: Then answered the Lord unto Job out of the whirlwind, and said,
38.2: Who is this that darkeneth the counsel by words without knowledge?
38.3: Gird up now thy loins like a man: I will demand of thee, and declare thou unto me.
38.4: Where wast thou when I laid the foundations of the earth? declare, if thou hast understanding.
38.5: Who hath laid the measures thereof, if thou knowest, or who hath stretched the line over it:
38.6: Whereupon are the foundations thereof set: or who laid the cornerstone thereof:
38.7: When the stars of the morning praised me together, and all the children of God rejoiced:
38.8: Or who hath shut up the Sea with doors, when it issued and came forth as out of the womb:
38.9: When I made the clouds as a covering thereof, and darkness as the swaddling bands thereof:
38.10: When I establisheth my commandment upon it, and set bars and doors,
38.11: And said, hitherto shalt thou come, but no further, and here shall it stay thy proud waves.
38.12: Hast thou commanded the morning since thy days? hast thou caused the morning to know his place?
38.13: That it might take hold of the corners of the earth, and that the wicked might be shaken out of it?
38.14: It is turned as clay to fashion, and all stand up as a garment.
38.15: And from the wicked their light shall be taken away, and the high arm shall be broken.
38.16: Hast thou entered into the bottoms of the sea? or hast thou walked to seek out the depth?
38.17: Have the gates of death been opened unto thee? or hast thou seen the gates of the shadow of death?
38.18: Hast thou perceived the breadth of the earth? tell if thou knowest all this.
38.19: Where is the way where light dwelleth? and where is the place of darkness,
38.20: That thou shouldest receive it in the bounds thereof, and that thou shouldest know the paths to the house thereof?
38.21: Knewest thou it, because thou wast then born? and because the number of thy days is great?
38.22: Hast thou entered into the treasures of the snow? or hast thou seen the treasures of the hail,
38.23: Which I have hid against the time of trouble, against the day of war and battle?
38.24: By what way is the light parted, which scattereth the East wind upon the earth?
38.25: Who hath divided the spouts for the rain? or the way for the lightning of the thunders,
38.26: To cause it to rain on the earth where no man is, and in the wilderness where there is no man?
38.27: To fulfill the wild and waste place, and to cause the bud of the herb to spring forth?
38.28: Who is the father of the rain? or who hath begotten the drops of the dew?
38.29: Out of whose womb came the ice? who hath engendered the frost of the heaven?
38.30: The waters are hid as with a stone: and the face of the depth is frozen.
38.31: Canst thou restrain the sweet influences of the Pleiades, or loose the bands of Orion?
38.32: Canst thou bring forth Mazzaroth in their time? canst thou also guide Arcturus with his sons?
38.33: Knowest thou the course of heaven, or canst thou set the rule thereof in the earth?
38.34: Canst thou lift up thy voice to the clouds, that the abundance of water may cover thee?
38.35: Canst thou send the lightnings that they may walk, and say unto thee, Lo, here we are?
38.36: Who hath put wisdom in the reins? or who hath given the heart understanding?
38.37: Who can number clouds by wisdom? or who can cause to cease the bottles of heaven,
38.38: When the earth groweth into hardness, and the clots are fast together?

39.1: Wilt thou hunt the prey for the lion? or fill the appetite of the lion’s whelps,
39.2: When they crouch in their places, and remain in the covert to lie in wait?
39.3: Who prepareth for the raven his meat, when his birds cry unto God, wandering for lack of meat?
39.4: Knowest thou the time when the wild goats bring forth young? or dost thou mark when the hinds do calve?
39.5: Canst thou number the months that they fulfill? or knowest thou the time when they bring forth?
39.6: They bow themselves: they bruise their young and cast out their sorrows.
39.7: Yet their young wax fat, and grow up with corn: they go forth and return not unto them.
39.8: Who hath set the wild ass at liberty? or who hath loosed the bonds of the wild ass?
39.9: It is I which have made the wilderness his house, and the salt places his dwellings.
39.10: He derideth the multitude of the city: he heareth not the cry of the driver.
39.11: He seeketh out the mountain for his pasture, and searcheth after every green thing.
39.12: Will the unicorn serve thee? or will he tarry by thy crib?
39.13: Canst thou bind the unicorn with his band to labor in the furrow? or will he plow the valleys after thee?
39.14: Wilt thou trust in him, because his strength is great, and cast off thy labor unto him?
39.15: Wilt thou believe him, that he will bring home thy seed, and gather it unto thy barn?
39.16: Hast thou given the pleasant wings unto the peacocks? or wings and feathers unto the ostrich?
39.17: Which leaveth his eggs in the earth, and maketh them hot in the dust,
39.18: And forgetteth that the foot might scatter them, or that the wild beast might break them.
39.19: He showeth himself cruel unto his young ones, as they were not his, and is without fear, as if he travailed in vain.
39.20: For God had deprived him of wisdom, and hath given him no part of understanding.
39.21: When time is, he mounteth on high: he mocketh the horse and his rider.
39.22: Hast thou given the horse strength, or covered his neck with neighing?
39.23: Hast thou made him afraid as the grasshopper? his strong neighing is fearful.
39.24: He diggeth in the valley, and rejoiceth in his strength: he goeth forth to meet the harnessed man.
39.25: He mocketh at fear, and is not afraid, and turneth not back from the sword,
39.26: Though the quiver rattle against him, the glittering spear and the shield.
39.27: He swalloweth the ground for fierceness and rage, and he believeth not that it is the noise of the trumpet.
39.28: He saith among the trumpets, Ha, ha: he smelleth the battle afar off, and the noise of the captains, and the shouting.
39.29: Shall the hawk fly by thy wisdom, stretching out his wings even toward the South?
39.30: Doth the eagle mount up at thy commandment, or make his nest on high?
39.31: She abideth and remaineth in the rock, even upon the top of the rock, and the tower,
39.32: From thence she spieth for meat, and her eyes behold afar off.
39.33: His young ones also suck up blood: and where the slain are, there is she.
39.34: Moreover the Lord spake unto Job, and said,
39.35: Is this to learn, to strive with the Almighty? he that reproveth God, let him answer to it.
39.36: Then Job answered the Lord, saying,
39.37: Behold, I am vile: what shall I answer thee? I will lay mine hand upon my mouth.
39.38: Once have I spoken, but I will answer no more, yea twice, but I will proceed no further.

40.1: Again the Lord answered Job out of the whirlwind, and said,
40.2: Gird up now thy loins like a man: I will demand of thee, and declare thou unto me.
40.3: Wilt thou disannul my judgment? or wilt thou condemn me, that thou mayest be justified?
40.4: Or hast thou an arm like God? or dost thou thunder with a voice like him?
40.5: Deck thyself now with majesty and excellency, and array thyself with beauty and glory.
40.6: Cast abroad the indignation of thy wrath, and behold everyone that is proud, and abase him.
40.7: Look on everyone that is arrogant, and bring him low: and destroy the wicked in their place.
40.8: Hide them in the dust together, and bind their faces in a secret place.
40.9: Then will I confess unto thee also, that thy right hand can save thee.
40.10: Behold now Behemoth (whom I made with thee) which eateth grass as an ox.
40.11: Behold now, his strength is in his loins, and his force is in the navel of his belly.
40.12: When he taketh pleasure, his tail is like a cedar: the sinews of his stones are wrapped together.
40.13: His bones are like staves of brass, and his small bones like staves of iron.
40.14: He is the chief of the ways of God: he that made him, will make his sword to approach unto him.
40.15: Surely the mountains bring him forth grass, where all the beasts of the field play.
40.16: Lieth he under the trees in the covert of the reed and fens?
40.17: Can the trees cover him with their shadow? or can the willows of the river compass him about?
40.18: Behold, he spoileth the river, and hasteth not: he trusteth that he can draw up Jordan into his mouth.
40.19: He taketh it with his eyes, and thrusteth his nose through whatsoever meeteth him.
40.20: Canst thou draw out Leviathan with an hook, and with a line which thou shalt cast down unto his tongue?
40.21: Canst thou cast an hook into his nose? canst thou pierce his jaws with an angle?
40.22: Will he make many prayers unto thee? and speak thee fair?
40.23: Will he make a covenant with thee? and wilt thou take him as a servant forever?
40.24: Wilt thou play with him as with a bird? or wilt thou bind him for thy maids?
40.25: Shall the companions banquet with him? shall they divide him among the merchants?
40.26: Canst thou fill the basket with his skin? or the fishpanier with his head?
40.27: Lay thine hand upon him: remember the battle, and do no more so.
40.28: Behold, his hope is in vain: for shall not one perish even at the sight of him?

41.1: None is so fierce that dare stir him up. Who is he then that can stand before me?
41.2: Who hath prevented me that I should make an end? All under heaven is mine.
41.3: I will not keep silence concerning his parts, nor his power, nor his comely proportion.
41.4: Who can discover the face of his garment? or who shall come to him with a double bridle?
41.5: Who shall open the doors of his face? his teeth are fearful round about.
41.6: The majesty of his scales is like strong shields, and are sure sealed.
41.7: One is set to another, that no wind can come between them.
41.8: One is joined to another: they stick together, that they cannot be sundered.
41.9: His sneezings make the light to shine, and his eyes are like the eyelids of the morning.
41.10: Out of his mouth go lamps, and sparks of fire leap out.
41.11: Out of his nostrils cometh out smoke, as out of a boiling pot or caldron.
41.12: His breath maketh the coals burn: for a flame goeth out of his mouth.
41.13: In his neck remaineth strength, and labor is rejected before his face.
41.14: The members of his body are joined: they are strong in themselves, and cannot be moved.
41.15: His heart is as strong as a stone, and as hard as the nether millstone.
41.16: The mighty are afraid of his majesty, and for fear they faint in themselves.
41.17: When the sword doth touch him, he will not rise up, nor for the spear, dart nor habergeon.
41.18: He esteemeth iron as straw, and brass as rotten wood.
41.19: The archer cannot make him flee: the stones of the sling are turneth into stubble unto him.
41.20: The darts are counted as straw: and he laugheth at the shaking of the spear.
41.21: Sharp stones are under him, and he spreadeth sharp things upon the mire.
41.22: He maketh the depth to boil like a pot, and maketh the Sea like a pot of ointment.
41.23: He maketh a path to shine after him, one would think the depth as an hoar head.
41.24: In the earth there is none like him: he is made without fear.
41.25: He beholdeth all high things: he is a King over all the children of pride.

42.1: Then Job answered the Lord, and said,
42.2: I know that thou canst do all things, and that there is no thought hid from thee.
42.3: Who is he that hideth counsel without knowledge? therefore have I spoken that I understood not, even things too wonderful for me, and which I knew not.
42.4: Hear, I beseech thee, and I will speak: I will demand of thee, and declare thou unto me.
42.5: I have heard of thee by the hearing of the ear, but now mine eye seeth thee.
42.6: Therefore I abhor myself, and repent in dust and ashes.
42.7: Now after that the Lord had spoken these words unto Job, the Lord also said unto Eliphaz the Temanite, My wrath is kindled against thee and against thy two friends: for ye have not spoken of me the thing that is right, like my servant Job.
42.8: Therefore take unto you now seven bullocks, and seven rams, and go to my servant Job, and offer up for yourselves a burnt offering, and my servant Job shall pray for you: for I will accept him, lest I should put you to shame, because ye have not spoken of me the thing which is right, like my servant Job.
42.9: So Eliphaz the Temanite, and Bildad the Shuhite, and Zophar the Naamathite, went, and did according as the Lord had said unto them, and the Lord accepted Job.
42.10: Then the Lord turned the captivity of Job, when he prayed for his friends: also the Lord gave Job twice so much as he had before.
42.11: Then came unto him all his brethren, and all his sisters, and all they that had been of his acquaintance before, and did eat bread with him in his house, and had compassion on him, and comforted him for all the evil that the Lord had brought upon him, and every man gave him a piece of money, and everyone an earring of gold.
42.12: So the Lord blessed the last days of Job more than the first: for he had fourteen thousand sheep, and six thousand camels, and a thousand yoke of oxen, and a thousand she asses.
42.13: He had also seven sons, and three daughters.
42.14: And he called the name of one Jemimah, and the name of the second Keziah, and the name of the third Keren-Happuch.
42.15: In all the land were no women found so fair as the daughters of Job, and their father gave them inheritance among their brethren.
42.16: And after this lived Job an hundred and forty years, and saw his sons, and his son’s sons, even four generations.
42.17: So Job died, being old, and full of days.
